headline: Wonton Wrappers
description: An original recipe for wonton wrappers — handmade from scratch. Use these to create tasty little dumplings stuffed with your favorite fillings.
name: Wonton Wrappers
recipeIngredient: 0.33333334326744 cup water, or more as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Beat egg in a medium bowl. Mix in 1/3 cup water.

Combine flour and salt in a large bowl. Create a well in the center of the flour mixture and slowly pour in egg and water. Mix well. If the mixture is too dry, increase the amount of water 1 teaspoon at a time until a pliable dough has formed.
Knead dough on a lightly floured surface until elastic. Cut dough into two separate balls. Cover dough balls with a damp cloth for a minimum of 10 minutes.
Cut each ball into four equal pieces. Roll the pieces into 10 1/2x10 1/2-inch squares. Then cut each square into nine 3 1/2x3 1/2-inch squares for a total of 72 wonton wrappers.

review.reviewBody: Really good. I used to make cream cheese wontons when I forgot to buy wrappers from the store. They don't turn out quite as crispy as store bought wontons when you fry, but my family said they actually preferred these. Will use again.
Worked out nice just had to keep adding more water as the kneading went on
I fantastic recipe. I can't get wonton wrappers where I live, so this recipe is my go to. I use it with Chef John's potsticker recipe, and they turn out perfect every time.
Instead of struggling to roll out a large surface, I split each ball into four and rolled them out thin and trimmed the edges
Worked well for pot stickers, not for crab rangoon. Had to do a lot of tweaking to get the dough right. Not the best.
I rolled the dough out, cut in strips and fries them for my egg drop soup. These were perfect! It only took a few minutes to make and they were so easy. Definitely saving this recipe!
yesss tastes good and is easy to make

Excellent wonton dough - worked with it easily to fill vegetarian egg-rolls with home-sprouted mung beans, slivers of carrot, green beans & cabbage. Dough rolled out thinly, very forgiving / stretchy & did not tear during 'construction '. Brushed with olive oil & baked - good results but next time may try trying in peanut oil.
Amazing recipe!!

Easy to make but definitely labor intensive and time-consuming. I let the dough rest 30 mins as others suggested and also left it under a damp cloth when I wasn’t working with it. Layered the cut out pieces between tea towels until I assembled my dumplings.
This recipe took *3 hours* to prep, roll, & cut the dough, not 30 minutes.
I really liked it. Was easy&fun!

Excellent recipe. Very simple. I no longer have a pasta roller, so I rolled these out the old fashioned way, with a bit of elbow grease! Even still, the outcome was great and the whole process took a little over an hour. Only hint I would add is to cut squares of parchment paper a bit larger than your wonton before you start. As you make them, they can be stacked with the parchment squares in between.
It takes a lot of work if you're hand-rolling but worth it. I did have to add an extra 2 1/2 teaspoons of water to make it work though.
I used these for Pork Dumplings. THEY ROCKED! It was a fun boredom buster for the covid19 shutdown.

This was an easy recipe. I followed it with a couple of exceptions. 1) I neaded for 10+ minutes to increase elasticity 2) let dough rest for an hour to relax gluten 3) used plenty of cornstarch when rolling. These slight adjustments made it a lot easier to form the noodles. Oh yes, I made these entirely by hand.... No food processor, mixer or pasta press.
I made the dough in my breadmaker, using the "dough kneading function" (which does not bake the dough). I also used high-gluten bread flour to make them super chewy. We loved the results!
Love this recipe!! Easy & perfect! Thank you for sharing! I will, however, ask for a pasta roller for Christmas!! LOL!
had to add a little extra water. I suggest rolling it out very thin but made a lot and held up well.

Turned out great. I read the reviews from others who tried to make this before. I used my kitchen aid mixer which helped a ton. I had to add an extra 1/4 cup of water as the dough was very crumbly. I added 1 teaspoon of water at a time until it finally formed a dough ball. So total was 1/4 cup of water. I let the dough rest for 30 mins. Then used my kitchen aid pasta roller attachment. Saved me so much time.

On my first attempt at making these wrappers, I learned not to be stingy with the flour. I should have dusted them or used wax paper between the layers when I stacked the finished wrappers on a plate. I had the most amazing looking tower of eggrolls, but when i went to fry them, two of them ripped because the were sticking together. Lesson learned. But the effort was still worth it, they came out absolutely delicious.
kids loved them stuffed them with leftover taco meat and cheese.
Have made 7 or 8 times now, cut up, and fried for use in egg drop soup. Sooo yummy!
It was good
Great dough for potstickers but not cream cheese wontons
Easy to follow and easy to make just time consuming filling them all but definitely worth it, they turned out delicious!
I had to double the egg and the water mixture because the dough was too tough and dry. Personally, this recipe was okay but it does need some changes.
So easy to make and turns out perfect everytime. Now I can have wontons whenever I want and not have to wait until I have the time to pick up the wrappers at a special store !

This takes a while to do. Rolling it out is a pain if you don't have a pasta machine. But I was set on making crab rangoons for a potluck and of course, none of the food markets that were open at 9 pm had wonton wrappers. 

So overall, great recipe. Everyone was incredibly impressed that I made everything by hand but it was a simple, foolproof recipe. I ran out of time so instead of resting with a damp cloth, I wrapped it in plastic wrap and let sit overnight in the fridge. Let it rest on the counter for about 10 minutes then rolled out with plenty of cornstarch. Don't use flour when rolling out. It will make it tacky. Use cornstarch!
It is a great recipe for wonton wrappers. The one reviewer brelax27 is not so bright, rating a 5 for the dough and a 1 for the work (GTFOH). The "work" is well worth the product.
my dough was thicker than usual wonton dough, and each quarter ball made 6, not 9, wrappers...but really yum!!
It is Great

Easy to mix up, a workout to roll them out. The recipe I made with these was awesome but the rolling out was difficult. Might have to buy a pasta machine to ease the burden. I will also try again letting the dough rest a bit more and perhaps using a bit less flour. 

Had no issues with them sticking together as there was enough of a flour dust on them after rolling.

makes a nice tender dough. I made it on the pasta dough setting, and rolled it out on my Atlas pasta machine to #6 
This will be my new go to recipe for this and I think Ravioli

Made these exactly as written.I used my pasta machine and they were so easy and quick to make I was amazed; however when I filled and fried was when the amazement really set in.These are better than I could have hoped for. 

ps .I cant imagine getting these rolled thin enough without the pasta machine.
Was good but highly suggest a pasta machine. Don't think it's possible to get to 10 1/2 in. by hand. I also used 2 extra teaspoons of water. Other than that was perfect for the crab ragoons!

I have a gluten allergy so I can get premade wontons. And I love n prefer to cook from scratch. Thank u for adding this recipe. I made wontons from scratch for the first time n then continued to make wonton soup. The only thing I have to do with try to roll out the wontons much thinner to make them like real wontons but my husband didn't complain so not bad for first time lol. Thanks again.
I used this to make wanton soup very simple and tastes good
Recipe turned out great, although I wasn't able to get 9 wrappers out of the smaller doughballs. For me, each small doughball was good for 1 egg roll or 2 crab rangoons.

I've grown up next to or near at least one oriental store my whole life, so it's been a struggle when I moved away. I've never had to make Wonton Wraps before but this recipe was great. I let the dough sit for 30 minutes and used a little less flour. Unfortunately, I did have to roll it out with a rolling pin and that was a tad time consuming. Making more today and I'm planning on using a circular cookie cutter, maybe that will cut 5 or 10 minutes off cooking time?
These are great! I wish I had a pasta machine because rolling them out thin enough was tedious. Also, don't skimp on the salt.

I have not made your recipe yet but wanted to add that when I spent time in Japan I made many of these into Gyoza, which is similar to a potsticker. I learned that after cutting these out and after making them to put them on waxed paper dusted with cornstarch and that is what keeps them from sticking together. I would make many pans of them and freeze them between the cornstarch dusted waxed paper that were layered high in a plastic container. When I wanted to fry some up, I would just take out what I needed. Very nice way of storing them!

These roll out fine with a rolling pin. I think you would get a better wrapper if you had a pasta machine. When the wrappers are cooked after using a rolling pin I felt like the wrappers were too thick. Tasted good, but not the thin wrappers you would expect.
I never made won ton wrappers from scratch before. This recipe was amazing! I made crab rangoon and the wrappers were perfect. I did use my pasta machine to roll the dough thin. Great recipe!!!!

Quick tip. Use a food processor and pulse it to bring the dough together. Knead it for a few minutes like you would pizza dough. I have a Marcato Atlas Wellness 150 Pasta Maker and I highly recommend it rather than rolling them out by hand. I make the wontons into 5" by 6" rectangles and make my own hot pockets. Put in pepperoni, mozzarella, and marinara sauce. Fry them up and then freeze them for quick lunches. MUCH better and cheaper than buying them at the store.

Perfect recipe for homemade wonton wrappers! I prefer to make everything myself when possible, used fresh eggs from my chickens. I used the wrappers for a pork dumpling recipe found here, and they worked perfectly. I followed the ingredients as listed, kneaded the dough till smooth, then I ran through my pasta machine down to about #3 thickness, cut into squares. I plan to keep the same recipe for larger wrappers, making egg rolls.

I made them exactly as the recipe says. Awesome! I was wondering though, has anyone tried to make them with other flours? Like rice, spelt or buckwheat? If so, how'd they turn out? 
Thanks for the recipe!

Incredibly good! I wanted to make crab ragoons and apparently where I live no one has ever heard of them because there was not a single store selling the right wrappers, only those rigid spring rolls wrappers. At 6 pm, after checking I don't know how many stores I was tired and I lost all hope. As usual when I'm desperate, I turned to Google for help and when I found this I couldn't believe it was so easy to make them. The best part is that while eating them what we liked the most wasn't the filling or the sauce but the crunchy, tasty wrapper. Life saver and better than anything store bought.

I use this recipe all the time! Mostly because we love crab rangoon and the other reason being wonton wrappers are not sold in our area. If I do have any criticism about this recipe, it is that the dough is often times hard to roll thin enough and almost never gets that bubbly, crispy outside that I expect. But overall, a great recipe!
These are perfect! They are every bit as good as store bought wanton wrappers! Thank you so much for posting this recipe! You're brilliant!
I rolled and cut the leftover dough into fresh pasta. A lovely light dough.

Used these to make some awesome veggie potstickers. To be fair, I have a Kitchenaid with a pasta roller, so that made it many many times easier to deal with. This is a very firm dough so, as previous comments said, having a pasta roller will make your life a lot better when you make a lot of pieces at a time.

I used this recipe to make cream cheese wontons. The texture was perfect! I didn't even have a rolling pin so I used a cylindrical glass to roll the dough. I put in some extra work, but I had so much fun. This is a great recipe

I have mixed feelings on these - I was really impressed with the few number of ingredients, and easy it was to make the dough. But I don't have a pasta maker, and had to roll these out by hand. The taste was good, but not worth the effort in the future.

thought it was going to be really hard, and i was afraid the whole time (i had no back up) that they wouldn't turn out. To my very pleasant surprise they turned out great! I couldn't get caught up in perfection, but once fried(I made egg rolls) they were awesome. Such a cheap option! You have to roll them out then and it does take time but I thought it was worth it!
What a fabulous find for the do it yourselfer! Make sure to dust with cornstarch tho. These noodles came out more tender than even my favorite Chinese restaurant... I'll definitely make these again!

This recipe worked out perfectly! I did need to add a bit more water, but that was all. The key to this dough is to allow it sit, covered at room temp to rest for easier rolling. The dough was beautiful to work with. I actually made the dough the day before, wrapped it and put it in the fridge. The next morning I took it out to come to room temp and 'rest'. I used a pasta machine to roll the dough to the thickness I wanted. Very easy and VERY delicious, waaaay better than store bought (and cheaper too)...A definite keeper~YUM! Thanks for sharing. :)
My dough would just not roll out thin enough so they ended up being a bit chewy when we ate them. The flavour was delicious though.

I used these for crab rangoons, yuuuum. Better than restaurant. I was a little worried about making this recipe at first because people said it was so hard to roll them by hand. I followed the recipe, except I let the dough rest for 45 minutes. They were so easy to roll out. Just make sure to roll them paper thin, or there will be waay to much dough when you fry them. I also used flour to knead the dough, and then mixed half flour half corn meal to roll them. Also, make sure to knead long enough, it took me 15 minutes. So don't think you need a pasta maker to make this recipe.
Hum...should have gone with my gut! An egg?! No, this was not the wrapper I was looking for!

I used my pasta maker to roll these out and it was actually really simple. Nice recipe, the dough is nice and easy to work with compared to others I have tried in the past. It would be a lot of work to roll out by hand though. I also used my Kitchen Aid with the dough hook to knead the dough.

I used this recipe for the won tons I made from another recipe on this site. I didn't mind rolling them out by hand. I enjoyed it. I also covered the dough with a wet towel while I mixed up my won ton filling. Then I went back to making squares. I didn't get them as thin as store bought won ton wrappers, but they still cooked up crispy.
Wonderful taste - my kids think these are fun to make. We stuff them with the no fry crab rangoon recipe from this site.
Sorry, I tried this and it didn't turn out.
I need more practice
Perfect recipe!! definitively agree with most of the comments. I had to add more water than the recipe says but in the end it all worked out!
How cool is this?????????? I halved recipe and made in food processor. Dough was lovely to work with after resting for half an hour. Had a blast making! Thanks so much for recipe.
Its a lot of hard work...a good recipe , don't get me wrong.
The recipe worked well and tasted good.

Honestly, this is a great recipe for wonton wrappers. My 13 yo that cooks...a lot, made them with no trouble in the preparation. The only really big issue is rolling this business out is HARD! We have since decided while it is nice to make wonton wrappers at home it is like making your own butter, it's just energy and cost effective to buy them from the store. The materials cost about as much at the store as buying the stuff and making it at home AND it taste just the same. But it was a fine recipe

Made by hand rolling when I couldn't find any wonton wrappers for a potstickers recipe in stores. These turned out exactly like the store-bought ones in terms of taste, I'll have to work on my rolling technique to make them more even in shape. Loved them, so simple and turn out wonderful.
They were easy and tasted just like store bought. I followed the directions exactly, except I mad a much smaller batch.

this recipe is perfect for a light and elastic dough that will fry up well ... but a couple of things i noticed, i definitely did not get 72 won ton wrappers out of this recipe. also, you have to be very careful about the dough sticking together so after assembling the won tons (or whatever else you're making) be sure to lay them out in a single layer on parchment paper (or something similar) and keep covered with a slightly damp towel. this dough did not work very well with baking. but this dough is definitely perfect for frying! i filled with curried mashed potatoes, sauteed onions, corn and peas. delicious!
Perfect! I used them to make gorgonzola buffalo chicken wraps... so delicious, didnt change a thing - let them sit for 40 minutes....

Got a late night pregnancy craving for cheese wontons. Found this recipe & it was very easy with a few tips. Make sure you let rest at least 30 minutes. Roll paper thin, or else they will be too pastry-like. If frying with a filling make sure you seal tight, dont want any cheese in the oil popping you!
Perfect
I had my doubts, but It was really good, I used my pasta machine to roll out the dough.
I dont know what I did wrong, but mine didnt turn out well at all. I was so hoping they would have.
I made these for chicken-cream cheese fried wontons and they were absolutely perfect! Fried up nicely and tasted just like a restaurant would make them! Yum!

This recipe was perfect. While it was annoying filling up all the wontons/dumplings this recipe yielded(about an hour with a rolling pin and pastry cutter), it tasted great and was easy to make. I already used these wrappers for gyoza, wonton soup and fried wonton. All came out great. I even filled some with a banana filling for a sweet dessert. I see no reason to change it or try anything else. Loved it.
Tried to use the wrappers to make egg rolls. Okay, but too thick and still mushy on the inside even when cooked until almost burnt. Even tried rolling them thinner than suggested in this recipe.

My son and I made this recipe yesterday and followed it exactly. We found the dough easy to work with and had no trouble at all except with the sheets sticking together. I suggest letting them cure a little individually before dusting with flour and stacking. Instead of making squares, we used a 3 1/2" circle cutter to make rounds and made potato, onion, and cheddar perogies. Any scraps I deep-fried and drizzled with honey and sprinkled with powdered sugar for a sweet snack. I had no wasted dough. Personally this is the recipe I'll use to make ravioli, dumplings, eggrolls, and perogies from now on. It is very versatile and easy to make.
I made potstickers for the kiddies. They came out amazingly great! Plus, I am making them again tonight for wonton soup. Thanks.
Wonderful recipe! Thanks for sharing!
Great recipe! I made for the 1st time tonight and now my husband is busy filling them. Definitely use a pasta roller to prepare the dough. Time saver and ensures the dough is thin enough.
Very easy and simple to make. They're also good fried in strips to make pita-like chips.
add a little flour to the mix. use immediately or the mixture will dry out.
Yummy wrappers.... i printed and put into my cookbook... i use this recipe all the time... i fill them with cream cheese or mozzarella cheese and pepperoni! YUM!!!
I loved this recipe it's quick and easy but my arms were sore after rolling out the dough :)

These worked out really well for me. I took the advise from one review to divide each ball into 9 pieces then rolled them out to the right thickness individually - that was a great tip. I filled them as I went too (made crab rangoons) and I was very pleased with this recipe.

a five for the actual dough. a 1 for the amount of work vs. product. if you don't have a pasta maker, and you can get wrappers from the store, save your self the frustration and hours of time and get the pre made wrappers.

I use this recipe for making fresh noodle, after the dough rest, I put in the pasta machine, and make it thin starting with #8 and go down to 1. Then I put thru the spaghetti cutter on the machine. This made a lot of noodle, you can freeze them and use it later.
Worked perfectly! Thank you!

Rolled them out bigger and used them as egg roll wrappers. Good for someone on a budget, but I think I'm probably going to splurge and buy the real thing next time, since it took quite a while to roll them out, and then it was tricky to wrap the egg rolls to cook.
I was makeing "CHINESE CHICKEN SALAD III ".From this site And used this recipe it was soo good will keep for the future.. Happy cookin!!! Thanks for sharing and God bless you...

Stoked I took the time to read reviews. Definitely cover with a warm towl and let rise for 30-45 minutes. I happen to be an extra unfortunate individual with nooo rolling pin. Took my bamboo cutting board and dusted it with flower. Flattened the dough out best I could by hand , pizza crust style. Then, with a dough scraper, cut the circle into six equal slices. Flattened out each piece and broke again into four pieces. Rolled all of the pieces into balls, let rest on parchment paper in between the board. I floured my board again and flattened each circle first with my palm, and then with the bottom of a measuring cup, also sprinkled in flour. I used the scraper to cut each circle into a square, then gave them on final mash. Made a few more with the circle scraps. Drained and pressed a can of spinach (usually use frozen, but had none on hand), sauteed 3/4 of an onion with a can of mushrooms in 2tbs butter, then tossed them in my mixer with 8oz room temp cream cheese. Filled the wraps and fried in sunflower oil. Made a dipping sauce with a little soy sauce, orange juice, and a tiny bit of oil/flour roux. Superb!
Worked well, I used wheat flour and only 1/2 the amount, yum
basic awesome recipe. Great in a pinch when you run out of pre-made wonton wrappers

I agree with others - let the dough rest for half an hour. As for rolling it out - I use a pasta machine. works like a champ. If you want thinner sheets yet, take two of the thinnest sheets and stack with plastic wrap between them. Roll them again and presto two sheets half the thickness.
